docblock.description: The database class allows you to send queries to a database server, run through results, and a lot more.

Return the active database object (or using the supplied id).

Gets the affected rows count from the last insert/delete/update/etc query.

Gets the next row from the mysqli_result object in an associative array.
Gets the next row from the mysqli_result object in a numerated array.
Clears the result set if a valid result object is provided.
Changes the current database.
Changes the current mysql user.
Expects to handle a select query.
Expects to handle a set query.
Expects to handle an optimize query.
Expects to handle a check query.
Expects to handle an insert query.
Expects to handle a delete query.
Expects to handle an update query.
Expects to be passed a numeric value to make sure it is safe.
Expects to be passed a non-numeric value to make sure it is safe.

docblock.description: The Locale class allows your application to support multiple languages.

docblock.description: The PzPHP core class is the central registry for modules, and allows quick access to them.
docblock.long-description: The PzPHP core class also allows you to register variables that can later be accessed in modules.

docblock.description: The version of PzPHP.
An array of registered modules and their instances.
An array of registered variables accessible to all modules.
The construct registers the core modules of PzPHP, including Pz_Core.
docblock.long-description: The construct also registers PzPHP's version with Pz_Core.

docblock.description: Checks to make sure key directories exist, and if they don't, create them.
Extracts all pz related constants to pass to Pz_Core.
Registers a module with PzPHP.
docblock.long-description: It does not get instantiated at this step.

docblock.description: Returns the instance of the specified module.
docblock.long-description: The module gets instantiated at this step if it has not already.

docblock.description: The security class gives you methods that allow you to create one-way, or two-way encryptions, among other things.
The init method takes care of applying custom security rules (if any).
Create a randomly generated string of characters.
Takes a string and creates a decryptable encryption.
Decrypts a string that was encrypted using the two-way method.
Creates a strong one-way encryption/hash.
docblock.long-description: This will generate a 44 character long hash by default (unless you have provided custom security rules (see init())).

docblock.description: Compare a string to a one-way hash string.
Compare a string to a two-way encrypted string.

docblock.description: A class extended by PzPHP modules to give easy access to the PzPHP core, among other things.

docblock.description: The Cache class gives you a layer of abstraction to access the caching options in the Pz Library.
docblock.long-description: The Cache class is agnostic to the type of caching (if any) you have configured PzPHP to use.

docblock.description: The established caching method (if any).
Flag if caching is enabled or not.
The contstruct verifies if caching is enabled, and sets it, if it is.
Verifies if caching is enabled, and sets the flag accordingly.
Sets the chosen caching method locally, and then returns its identifier.
Returns true or false depending on if caching is enabled or not.
Returns the identifier for the current caching method.
Add a cache server (if using mecache).
Cache read without a lock check and set.
docblock.long-description: Reads from the cache without setting a lock, or checking for one.

docblock.description: Cache read with a lock check and set.
docblock.long-description: Reads from the cache, checking for a lock first (and waiting if one is present), and then sets a lock once the previous lock (if any) is removed.

docblock.description: Cache write without a lock delete.
docblock.long-description: Writes to the cache without deleting a lock on the specified key.

docblock.description: Cache write with a lock delete.
docblock.long-description: Writes to the cache as well as deletes a lock (if present) on the specified key.

docblock.description: Cache delete without a lock check.
docblock.long-description: Deletes key from the cache without checking for a lock.

docblock.description: Cache delete with a lock check.
docblock.long-description: Deletes key from the cache, checking for a lock first before deleting.

docblock.description: Contributions by: Fayez Awad Yann Madeleine (http://www.yann-madeleine.com)

docblock.description: Pz's main settings array
docblock.long-description: A multi-dimensional array that holds default settings for Pz.

docblock.description: An array where mysql server objects are stored.
docblock.long-description: They keys in this array also act as the id for the particular mysql server object.

docblock.description: The active mysql server id.

docblock.description: The active memcached server id.
The active memcache server id.
Boot-up process for the Pz Library.
docblock.long-description: This is where settings are set (if any custom settings are provided), debugging is started (if enabled), and security checks are executed (if need be).

docblock.description: Disconnects any active connection to a mysql or memcache server, as well as tell the debugger to run its finalize step (if enabled).
docblock.long-description:
The destruct procedure allows you to avoid having to manually disconnect your mysql or memcache servers.

Of course, you can choose to disconnect them at any time before this destruct procedure.

docblock.description: Apply any custom settings for Pz before anything else gets started.
Begin debugging class, or warm-up logs.
Begin basic server security checks (if enabled).
docblock.long-description: This will do a domain check, whitelist check, and blacklist check.

docblock.description: Any other functions that need to be executed at start-up are called here.
Registers an object in the Pz objects array.
Gets a registered object from the Pz objects array.
Loads a Pz Interaction for a specific submodule.
docblock.long-description: New interactions are passed an instance of Pz_Core in their constructor.

docblock.description: Gets a loaded Pz Interaction.
Gets a Pz setting's value.
Returns true if server security is needed/enabled.
Returns the Pz_Security object (also autoloads it if not already loaded).
Returns the Pz_Http_Request object (also autoloads it if not already loaded).
Returns the Pz_Http_Response object (also autoloads it if not already loaded).
Returns the logger object for a specified subpackage.
Adds a custom log entry to a specified log file (via a logger object).
Executes a method inside the debugger object (if it exists).
Method that compresses buffered output (started with ob_start()).
docblock.long-description:
HTML code is compressed to one line, with whitespaces removed.

Sections of the html can be ignored from compression using:

...HTML and code that wont be compressed goes here...

When compressing output, make sure not to use unclosed comments in inline javascript and css (i.e. //comment here... )

docblock.description: Disconnects all registered Mysql servers (using Mysqli).
docblock.long-description: You have the option to not have them unregistered with Pz after being disconnected.

docblock.description: Disconnects a particular mysql server (using Mysqli).
docblock.long-description:
If a specific id is not given, the current active mysqli server object will be disconnected.

You have the option to not have it unregistered with Pz after being disconnected.

docblock.description: Registers a mysql server with Pz (using Mysqli).
docblock.long-description:
By default, the mysql server is not connected to until you send a specific command to it (like a query).

This method handles everything that is needed to register a mysql server object with Pz (using Mysqli).

docblock.description: Unregisters a mysql server object with Pz (using Mysqli).
docblock.long-description:
If no specific server is specified, the active server object will be used.

This method will disconnect from the server automatically.

docblock.description: Connects to the mysql server (using Mysqli).
Sets the active mysql server id (using Mysqli).
docblock.long-description: By default, this method will not auto connect to the mysql server.

docblock.description: Returns the current active mysql server id (using Mysqli).
Returns the current active mysql server object (using Mysqli).
docblock.long-description: If an id is specified, then the specified mysler server object will be returned instead.

docblock.description: Returns the interaction object for mysqli.
Resolves the proper mysql server object id based on input.
docblock.long-description: If the input id is -1, then the active id is returned, else, the id is returned.

docblock.description: Disconnects all registered Mysql servers (using Mysql).
docblock.long-description: You have the option to not have them unregistered with Pz after being disconnected.

docblock.description: Disconnects a particular mysql server (using Mysql).
docblock.long-description:
If a specific id is not given, the current active mysqli server object will be disconnected.

You have the option to not have it unregistered with Pz after being disconnected.

docblock.description: Registers a mysql server with Pz (using Mysql).
docblock.long-description:
By default, the mysql server is not connected to until you send a specific command to it (like a query).

This method handles everything that is needed to register a mysql server object with Pz (using Mysql).

docblock.description: Unregisters a mysql server object with Pz (using Mysql).

If no specific server is specified, the active server object will be used.

This method will disconnect from the server automatically.

docblock.long-description: If the input id is -1, then the active id is returned, else, the id is returned.

docblock.description: Disconnects all registered database servers (using PDO).
docblock.long-description: You have the option to not have them unregistered with Pz after being disconnected.

docblock.description: Disconnects a particular database server (using PDO).

If a specific id is not given, the current active PDO server object will be disconnected.

You have the option to not have it unregistered with Pz after being disconnected.

By default, the database server is not connected to until you send a specific command to it (like a query).

docblock.description: The Pz Crypt class implements strong hashing and encryption methods to help protect sensitive information.
Flag for two-way encryption.
Flag for one-way encryption.
Flag for strict hashing/encryption.
Custom rules flag array key for override hash.
Custom rules flag array key for override salt.
Custom rules flag array key for override poison constraints.
Custom rules flag array key for override unique salt.
Flag to indicate encrypted string is poisoned.
This passphrase is required when generating or verifying environment info.
docblock.long-description: Using a passphrase means it wont be possible for somoene to call the public function from another program, without direct access to the source of this class

docblock.description: How many times should the default/custom salt be hashed by the default hashing algorithm.
Must exist in hash_algos() array.
It is recommended you change this salt as to distinguish yourself from other Pz_Crypt installations/hashes
Poison constraints are used when poisoning a hashed or encrypted string.
docblock.long-description:
Poisoning greatly increases the difficulty for crackers to find the original protected string.

Every sub-array has two elements: - the first element dictates at which point in the string will the poisoning begin - the second element dictates how long the poison will be (all in characters)

It is good to provide constraints for long strings as well, even if you know you wont be feeding Pz_Crypt long strings.

docblock.description: This array is used for the source character to be shifted.
This array is used for the character to replace the original character with.
Encrypt allows you to encrypt or hash a string in a one-way or two-way algorithim.
docblock.long-description:
The flags array can hold any of the following (as values):

TWO_WAY = default flag sent that tells Pz_Crypt to produce a two-way encryped string. Pz_Crypt uses its own hash and algorithim to produce the ecnrypted string.

ONE_WAY = flag that tells Pz_Crypt to produce a one-way encrypted string. Pz_Crypt uses a special algorithim to encrypt strings

STRICT = hashes produced in ONE_WAY encryption will honor the $kHash property's length and character type. eg. md5 generates 32 hex char hashes, so Pz_Crypt will honor that

The custom rules array can hold any of the following (as key => values):

HASH => overwrite the default hash algorithim set by $kHash. Make the the hash is supported by your system/php build

SALT => if you want to use a custom salt, then include this rule, if you want to use Pz_Crypt's default salt, then do not include this rule

POISON_CONSTRAINTS => If you dont want any poisoning, then provide an empty array. If you want to use Pz_Crypt's default poison constraints, then dont include this rule

UNIQUE_SALT => A unique salt that you want to apply to this password. Unique salts make password has reversal much harder, since crackers must figure out which unique salt was used for each password hash.

docblock.description: Decrypt is used for revealing the original encrypted string.
docblock.long-description:
The flags array can hold any of the following (as values):

DE_POISON = de-poison the string first

The custom rules array can hold any of the following (as keys => values):

POISON_CONSTRAINTS => use this only if you overwrote the defualt poison constraints during encryption

docblock.description: This method compares two strings (one hashed, one unhashed) to see if they are the same.
docblock.long-description:
You can compare both one-way and two-way strings in this way.

The flags array can hold any of the values that the encrypt() method expects.

The custom rules array can hold any of the values that the encrypt() method expects.

docblock.description: Poisons a string using the passed-in poison constraints.
De-poisons a string based on the passed-in poison constraints.
Will return a string that will include various info about the current setup of this class and relevant php/system settings.
docblock.long-description:
You should use this once you go production, and store the string somewhere safe.

In the event that you must switch servers, make sure to run that string through the verifyChecksum() method, as to make sure the new system will support all of the encrypted strings you have generated on the previous system.

NOTE: This verification method cannot take into account custom rules you may have passed in to the encrypt method, so do not soley rely on this method to verify compatibility.

NOTE: This verification method will not take into account your passphrase.

docblock.description: Verifies a checksum with the current server and configuration.
Will dump a new array to replace the defualt $hashTableFrom array.
Replaces the default Pz_Crypt hash.
Regenerates a new Pz_Crypt salt.
Replaces the default Pz_Crypt salt.
Regenerates a new array of poison constraints to replace the default array.
Replaces the default Pz_Crypt poison constraints.
Replaces the default Pz_Crypt rehash depth value.
Contributions by: Fayez Awad Yann Madeleine (http://www.yann-madeleine.com)
docblock.long-description: Licensed under The MIT License Redistributions of files must retain the above copyright notice, contribtuions, and original author information.
